title: Car Insurance Study
question_text:
An insurance company commissioned a study to examine the connection between age and whether or not a person had ever been in a car accident. The graph below summarizes the data.

Which of the following is supported by the chart?

choices.text: The age group with the smallest proportion of drivers with accidents is 16−20 years old.
As you get older, you are less likely to be in a car accident.

The age group with the highest proportion being in a car accident is 30−50
year old.

A person in the 21−30
year old category is more likely to have been in a car accident than not.

In the 50+
age category, less than 50%
of people surveyed had been in a car accident.

solution:
The data above is summarized in a segmented bar chart, which is an example of bar graph for one categorical variable, broken down by categories of another variable. In this case, the variables are age group and whether or not the person had been in a car accident.

Looking at the
16
−
20
age group, only about
10
%
of people surveyed answered "Yes". Which, when looking at the other age groups, is by far the smallest proportion to answer "Yes".

Choice 'A' is correct.
